newsitem.title: USA: 'God Tax' soundly defeated in Colorado.
newsitem.headline: 'God Tax' soundly defeated in Colorado.

text.p: Colorado churches, synogogues, mosques and other non-profit organizations will keep their tax exempt status following the resounding defeat of Amendment 11, dubbed the 'God Tax,' election results show.
Colorado voters rejected the measure by a strong 83 to 17 percent margin.
Churches and non profits campaigned heavily against the measure and signs saying "No on 11" could be seen planted on church lawns.

Proponents of the measure, which would allowed churches to maintain their status if they engaged in certain work such as teaching or providing meals or shelter to the homeless, , said non-profits benefited from things like fire and police protection and needed to help pay for those services.

But voters feared government services would have to be increased to make up for the work that non-profits might no longer have been able to provide. The slogan "Don't hurt the helpers" apparently persuaded voters agains the measure.

Also, under Colorado's complex tax laws residential property taxes would probably not have been lowered if the measure had been approved, opponents argued. Current law provides for a ratio between residential and non-residential tax revenues. If non-profits paid taxes, businesses might have gotten the tax break.
